summary.p: Bullinger recommends [Jakob] Metzler, who is returning [to Constance] and has conducted himself well in [Zurich]. The [Zurichers] hope that Metzler will be useful to the church one day, especially if he expands his abilities through constant study.
- Greetings, especially to [Thomas Blarer], [Konrad] Zwick, [Bartholomäus] Metzler, and [Jakob] Funcklin.

div.p: Grace and peace. Your Metzler, dearest Ambrosius, returns to you with our good grace. For he conducted himself among us in such a way that we are going to praise him and always consider him as one of our own, even if he has not returned. If he returns, we will gladly receive him again. We hope that he will be of considerable benefit to the church someday, especially if he continues to enrich and enhance his talents through constant and uninterrupted study. Therefore, we commend him to you, to your father, and to all good people. May the Lord Jesus keep both you and him safe for a long time.
Farewell. Zurich, March 29. Greet your brother, Konrad Zwick, Bartholomäus Metzler, Jakob Funcklin, and all the brothers and fellow students. 1546.
To the most excellent man, Ambrosius Blarer, incomparable brother. Constance.
